newsitem.title: JORDAN: Mubarak and King Hussein review peace process.
newsitem.headline: Mubarak and King Hussein review peace process.

text.p: King Hussein discussed on Tuesday with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak efforts to overcome obstacles to progress in the stalled Middle East peace talks, officials said.

They said King Hussein, who met Mubarak during a stop at Amman airport from Damascus where he had talks with Syrian President Hafez al-Assad, also discussed coordinating their positions on latest efforts to push ahead stalled Israeli-Palestinian talks.

"The meeting continues what we have become accustomed to from time to time. It was an opportunity to discuss matters relating to the peace process, the region and bilateral ties," the monarch told reporters after Mubarak's departure.

"We continue to demand ensuring a just, permanent and honourable solution to the central cause in this part of the world and naturally we support our Palestinian brothers to the utmost of our capabilities," he said.

King Hussein also praised active Egyptian diplomacy in the region to help jump start Israeli-PLO peace talks in crisis since March when Israel broke ground on a 6,500-home Jewish settlement on an Arab East Jerusalem hill.
The monarch said Jordan's role was a supportive one.

"We have been working closely together, Egypt has played a very major role which only Egypt can play and our position has been a complementary one to Egypt in all that has happened so far," the monarch said.
King Hussein also briefed Mubarak on talks held earlier in Amman with Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy which encouraged some optimism about renewed progress, officials said.

"No doubt he (Levy) gave us the impression that he was concerned with the peace process...and that he had a programme that created optimism about its possible implementation soon to help resolve outstanding issues and then continue peace talks with the Palestinians," the king said.

Tuesday's diplomatic activity comes a day after Israel put the brakes on a plan to build a new Jewish enclave in Arab East Jerusalem and agreed to resume talks with the PLO on meeting commitments made under their interim peace deals.

Foreign Minister Fayez al-Tarawnah said after talks with Levy that Jordan was relieved by Israel's move to defuse tension by halting permits of the new settler plan, saying it was a confidence building step which could relaunch peace talks.
